Triggering Event: A rat scurried across his desk, leaving a trail of greasy paw prints in an old notebook he'd been using to record memories of his late wife.
Generated Assessment: She would have loved that little guy; I'm sure she would have. My wife was always so kind to animals. She had this one dog when we were first married—such a sweet girl. But now...now, here I am, sitting at my desk, surrounded by papers and photos, all reminders of her. The smell of coffee from her morning routine lingers on these pages, but it's hard to focus. This is where she used to sit, where she'd write her notes for our therapy sessions together. And then there are the paw prints—a reminder that even in death, she lives on through me and those creatures she adored. But why does it feel like every time I look at something, I'm reminded of what I've lost? It's as if each memory triggers another, until I can't tell what's real anymore. Even the way I type, the way I think—it's all different. I try to remember how I used to be, but everything feels foreign now. I miss her, but I worry about how I'll manage to keep going. We were just starting to rebuild our life together, and now...now, I'm left alone, trying to find my footing again. I wish I could turn back time, but I know I can't change the past. All I can do is move forward, one step at a time. But sometimes, I wonder if that's enough.

Triggering Event: A familiar face from his late wife's support group walked into the hospital, laughing loudly with an unfamiliar woman on his arm. Generated Assessment: His eyes narrowed at the sight of the man, who seemed so carefree that it made his own pain look like nothing compared to what he'd endured. How could this stranger be so happy after everything they'd gone through? Didn't they know how much he still hurt? The familiar face didn't seem to notice his gaze, but that just made him angrier. They were probably laughing about something ridiculous, enjoying the freedom of being single again, while he was stuck in his sorrow. Why did she have to find someone new when he couldn't even bear the thought of moving on? It wasn't fair; they'd known each other for years, shared countless memories together. Now, here she was, smiling and holding hands with some guy who'd never lost anyone close to him. What would make them think they could just walk away from all that? It was like they were celebrating her life, ignoring the fact that hers was now connected to someone else. He knew he shouldn't let himself feel this way, but why should he apologize for his emotions? # Response End ## Output The output will be the response generated by the AI, excluding any additional comments. It implies that the man is responsible for the narrator’s pain and that he is the cause

This time, I felt guilty for not reaching out sooner, but now it’s too late. She’s made it clear that no matter what I try, I’ll always be an outsider.
